files.patch:
@@ -896,1 +896,1 @@ -

You must also make sure your build does not rely on configure's default adhoc version strings. Default adhoc version strings OPT segment include user name, source directory and timestamp. You can either override just the OPT segment using --with-version-opt=<any fixed string>, or you can specify the entire version string using --with-version-string=<your version>.

+

You must also make sure your build does not rely on configure's default adhoc version strings. Default adhoc version strings OPT segment include user name and source directory. You can either override just the OPT segment using --with-version-opt=<any fixed string>, or you can specify the entire version string using --with-version-string=<your version>.

@@ -905,1 +905,1 @@ -

This option controls how the JDK build sets SOURCE_DATE_ EPOCH when building. It can be set to a value describing a date, either an epoch based timestamp as an integer, or a valid ISO-8601 date.

+

This option controls how the JDK build sets SOURCE_DATE_EPOCH when building. It can be set to a value describing a date, either an epoch based timestamp as an integer, or a valid ISO-8601 date.

@@ -1545,4 +1545,4 @@
-version strings. Default adhoc version strings `OPT` segment include user name,
-source directory and timestamp. You can either override just the `OPT` segment
-using `--with-version-opt=<any fixed string>`, or you can specify the entire
-version string using `--with-version-string=<your version>`.
+version strings. Default adhoc version strings `OPT` segment include user name
+and source directory. You can either override just the `OPT` segment using
+`--with-version-opt=<any fixed string>`, or you can specify the entire version
+string using `--with-version-string=<your version>`.
@@ -1570,1 +1570,1 @@
